review_body: I stayed here in November when it was super rainy. Granted you have the entrance to Takebashi Metro station right outside the door, but there are no lifts from the underground - only long flights of stairs, so it will be difficult with heavy luggage.Also, the same category of single rooms have 2 types - one at the long side of the building with much bigger space, and one more type at the shorter side of the building with much lesser space. As for the toilet in the rooms - some rooms are more updated, compared to the others, so the washlet toilets are much better, whereas the older ones aren't as good. Other than that, I think it's a fairly standard business hotel -nothing fancy. Also, if you book a twin room, make sure to write TWIN there - they gave me a double bed for my twin room, which made for some laughs when my friend and I checked in.

The standard room was 'Japanese size' but surprising the bathtub was full size. Small 'nook' for hanging clothes with no door, a nice desk to work on with a mirror in front, full-length mirror by the entrance door. 2 electric sockets in the bathroom and 2 more by the desk. A minifridge in a cabinet attached to the desk. Green and brown tea (1 each) every day with the hot pot for boiling water. The TV is maybe 42 inches (didn't measure) but I didn't use it because all I found were Japanese shows. Might have others but couldn't read the remote buttons as they were in Japanese and I was busy so no time to watch. If you want a Japanese breakfast, you need to buy the vouchers. Coffee/tea, salad, beans and edamame, tomatoes and some egg and franks, fried potatoes. BEST was the croissants with really nice blueberry conserve with tons of whole blueberries inside. A separate Japanese table with more local favourites. Entrance to the underground train right out the front door and a block walk underground to the train. Limited food options for lunch or dinner but within 5 or 6 blocks, many more options if you turn LEFT out the front door. Front desk staff do not all speak English but the would summon someone who did speak it fairly well.

The hotel is a classic mid-range hotel, looking rather dated in design and layout but has plenty to recommend it. Each floor has several vending machines that provide alcohol, drinks and food, like a mini convenience store. There is a large wedding venue inside that can be seen from several floors. Located close to the Imperial Palace, so you can visit or go for that early morning jog. The Takebashi subway station is right by the hotel's entrance (though there are no lifts, and there are a lot of stairs - unfortunate if you have several heavy luggage). Breakfast choices include continental or Japanese. There is a cafe on the ground floor but the breakfast restaurant is actually on the 12th floor.

I stayed in this hotel for 4 nights for a business trip. The hotel is very well located, with 1 min walk to the Takebashi station and 10 min walk from the Imperial Palace.My room is a deluxe single room so it is of a reasonable size in Tokyo standard. My friend stayed in a regular single which is rather small. The room is generally tidy with basic equipment and bath provisions. The decoration is rather old school without any impressive features. The staff are friendly and helpful, keeping the good Japanese standard.Overall, this is an average hotel for short stay or travelers looking for a reasonable room rate in Tokyo.

First time in Tokyo: Experience in the hotel was too good for me. I like small and cozy rooms. All the amenities were there along with a bathtub. Nothing else I can ask for.Very helpful staffs.Nice cafe.Very convenient for metro.I recommend Hotel KKR in Tokyo.

This is a clean well run hotel. It is located next to a metro stop which is convenient (although if coming with suitcases from airport there is a lot of stairs for bags). The staff are very accomodating. The breakfast buffet is good and has a lovely view of the park. This hotel has a wedding venue in the middle of it and I would think its mostly aimed at weddings and parties.

I stayed at this hotel when in a business trip to Tokyo. I arrived at around 0600 having flown in from London. Some what disappointed when they said I had to wait till 3 for check in, but it was the night staff so went for a walk around the Edo palace walls, very nice, and then had a coffee at starbucks, I got back to the hotel at around 1030, and asked about the room, they asked me to wait a few minutes and then gave me the room key, for which i was very grateful. The room was lovely with a view over the palace, it was spotlessly clean. I did have breakfast the next day but decided not to bother after that, it was a somewhat limited choice. I would stay in the hotel again because of its location.

The checkin process was very easy. The room was clean and bright and cosy! The hotel was located next to a metro stop. The area is not interesting and the restaurants nearby were not that special. I travelled outside of Chiyoda for food and for exploring.

Good location, great views, and tasty breakfast. As a 3- or 4-star hotel, this has a lot going for it. I've travelled a lot in Japan, but this was my first time to be surprised at the room not having been cleaned very well. Dusty shelf (where we're supposed to put clothes) and dirty carpet ... Really, since everything else is so good, why let yourselves down on this?!

I love this hotel's location since it is just across the road from Imperial Palace's ground where many people do the morning run.However, the hotel is quite far from shopping centres and minimarts (the closest one is around 7-10 minutes walk).The lobby is very large so that you will have a comfortable feeling. Amenities is to be expected from Japanese hotels with pajamas cloak. The room is small but comfortable.WiFi speed is extremely fast, up to 45.38 mbps.

The KKR hotel is located really close to the Imperial Garden, and not particularly far from Tokyo Station. The rooms are located on the top floors so you get a good view over Tokyo. My room, on the 14th floor, both had nice views over part of the imperial garden as well seeing Mt. Fujii in the far distance. The room was big enough and the bed provided good sleep quality. The bath room was equipped with a bathtub. It was well maintained. There are some restaurants in the hotel. We had a one day conference at the hotel and we had both lunch and a more luxurious dinner in the Japanese restaurant. The food and service was of good quality. When travelling, you will probably arrive at Tokyo Station. You can easily walk to the hotel. The distance is about 1.5 km one way. The iPhone map works well and will give you good instructions. If you have spare time, I recommend a walk in the imperial garden. If you are not so keen on hotel restaurants, I recommend a short walk towards north when leaving the hotel. There you will find a variety of smaller, not expensive, restaurants, including McDonald’s. I enjoyed a splendid tempura set meal an evening in one of these restaurants. I had also a cheeseburger, of course, for lunch one day. My experience relating to Tokyo is that you do not really need to fear facing a bad meal experience, even if you pick a kind of rudimentary place for dinner.

Stayed at KKR for 12 days. Overall, it was pleasant stay. My room faced the high way and the imperial palace, which is nice. The room is clean given the age of the hotel. The hallway may look a little beat up but the room remains its clean standard. The room size is decent when comparing to some other popular hotels. Staff are friendly and can speak English with us. We also ordered the breakfast package and the food selection was good. They have both Western and Japanese style breakfast. Open from 6:30am to 9am. Since we have been there for 12 days, the selection gets a little boring. However, I wouldn’t mind if I am there for 3-5 days. The only drawback for this location is that if you take subway from Haneda airport. There is no elevator for you to bring your luggages up, although the hotel is just right above the station. You may take taxi but it will cost you. Unfortunately, there is no shuttle bus to the hotel from airport. Other than that, I think this is a nice hotel and I wouldn’t mind going back if there is shuttle bus going there.

Stayed here for a school trip for 2 weeks. The location is very convenient to walk to Hitotsubashi ICS. The station takebashi is right outside the lobby so that’s nice. The rooms is small but I guess standard for Japan. You have wifi, tiny fridge, kettle, blow dryer as the essentials. The breakfast is good if you’re staying for a couple of days. However after 2 weeks the food is soooooooo boring and you would get so tired of the same thing over and over...

Dropby for 2 nights stay, nice location near Otemachi, The hotel is just next to Takebashi Station.From hotel can have A nice view to imperial palace.Accessible to subway easily, staffs can say a minimum English. Overall hotel room structure quite okay at a fair level. Recommended.

Room: Good size--could hold my large suitcase, carry on and purse with a lot of space leftover. Bathroom was a good size as well. AC cooled downed the room quickly once you arrived. Cleaning staff was great. WIFI was great and you could stream and skype.Location: People already pointed out that it was close to the Imperial palace but it is also about a 20 minute walk to Kanda (food) and Ginza (shopping). Even closer are streets with a lot of restaurants and karoke. So, it is close to every thing that you might need. The subway is right outside the main entrance--it is a lot of stairs but if you walk on street level for a few minutes, you could reach the elevator. I walked from Tokyo station but you can easily hail a cab and the subway is a little faster than walking.Breakfast: There were juices, fresh sliced orange, grapefruit, pineapple, and fruit cocktail It's about half western. The western half included: corn flakes, potatoes (french fries), eggs, ham OR bacon, croissants, and rolls. The Japanese half included: clam fried rice, miso soup, tofu, egg, rice, salad, fish and dessert. I was at the hotel for eight days and only at the tail end of my trip was I getting tired of the selection.Staff: Friendly and helpful. As a solo traveler, they only provided one set of towels and it was easy to get another set quickly. I would 100% stay here again especially for the value. I stayed at a hotel nearby for the same price point and this hotel was WAY better.

It takes not less than 15 or 20 minutes to walk from Tokyo bullet train(Shinkansen) station to this hotel.But, it is not so far compared to other hotels in this area.This hotel is one of the facilities for Japanese public agency union (KKR). So you may feel some different atmosphere in this hotel compared to other hotels. I hope you will be accustomed to it soon.This hotel will answer your minimum expectation for three star hotels. To my regret, you'd better not expect more hospitality than it, though.[Some urgent improvements needed:]Stronger pressure of shower water and regular maintenance needed.Improving and regular maintenance of air conditioner needed.(My throat had a trouble because of the cool air of it.)The breakfast time zone for the guest is from 6:30 to 9:00. It is very short, and should be expanded from 6:30 to 10:00. And I'd appreciate if the check out time would be changed from 11:00 to 12:00.[Advise for the foreign travellers:]Take the Marunouchi Shuttle Free Bus from Mitsubishi Building(from TYO Marunouchi South Exit) or Shin-Marunouchi Building(from TYO Marunouchi North Exit) to Nikkei Building. It is definitely more convenient for you than near subway station which is very inconvenient for old people and children (too long concourse and no elevators and escalators). You need about 5 minutes walk from Nikkei to the hotel. But, please note this is very slow speed bus, especially when you want to return to TYO station from Nikkei. You have to take enough time to use this system.

Literally next door to the subway station entry, so handy for travelling around Tokyo.Good quality and plentiful toiletries. Superb view of Imperial Gardens from the room. Nearly took off a point for no coffee in room, but given all else thought this would have been churlish. I would also add that there are a lot of stairs between getting off the subway and reaching the hotel. Added advantage is that as it is opposite the Imperial Gardens it is easy to locate. All told excellent value. And the WiFi works well, this is just as well as all TV channels are in Japanese, no satellite TV that I found.Hotel has laundry room

Room was good size with work desk and fast internet. Next to subway station and convenient to shops and restaurants. Staff friendly and helpful. Breakfast buffet good with both Japanese and Western fare.

A hotel at a great location. All the rooms are in the top floor of the building and offer stunning views of Tokyo. Situated right next to a subway station (Takebashi, Tozai Line), you benefit from a very easy access to the public transport network. Perfect for the joggers, because the hotel is located right at the Imperial Palace garden(Kōkyo). Hotel staff is very helpful and friendly and the room prices are astonishingly reasonable for what you get. The room was spacious and comfortable and amenities offered all you could wish for. Absolutely recommendable!

Stayed for 2 nights for the work nearby, used a taxi first but noticed it took only 10 min walk.Room was clean, specious compared to the same class of hotels, could see a little bit Imperial Palace, most of the part was construction building, though.Bed and towel was clean but very hard.WiFi worked very well.Convenience store was within 5 min walk, TULLY's was within 3 min.Breakfast buffet open 6:30-9:00, 1400JPY, mainly Japanese foods. I may need to stay in this area few more times and will choose this hotel again.

I stayed there 5days. The room was not narrow compared to Japanese business hotels. The hotel near the imperial house. So if you want to running, best location.部屋は通常のビジネスホテルに比べると、広いしベッドも寝心地がいいです。東京駅の丸の内北口から徒歩10分から15分程です。洗濯機があるフロアがあるので、長期滞在にも便利ですし、皇居の周りを走れるので、ランニングをされる方にはもってこいです！宿泊料金は5泊して、一泊平均10,000円でした。

Takebashi station is right outside the main door of the hotel. Subway transport is thus convenient going to and returning from anywhere in Tokyo. My business trip in the Otemachi area was a basis for my selecting this hotel. No need to ride. My wife and I occupied a room overlooking the Imperial Palace. It was a beautiful scenery. Being in this location makes you want to exercise with long walks inside the Palace grounds and also around the Palace, close to the moat. It looks like a major hiking and jogging area, especially during the weekend.The vicinity of the hotel is quiet. The glass insulation is very good - there's hardly any street noise from the expressway running on one side of the hotel.Housekeeping kept our room and bathroom consistently spic and span. The yukata is replaced daily. Hotel staff are always helpful. Among a few of them, English capability is not well developed, so if there's an explanation you needed about something, it takes a while before you come to some understanding. But they try their best.It's usually the case in Japanese hotels that your cable TV programs are all in Japanese. You catch CNN and BBC news in English only late at night and early in the morning (I'm not sure if it happened only at this hotel.) anyway, for me, that was not a major inconvenience.My wife and I were very satisfied with our 8 nights at this wonderful hotel.

This hotel is located near the Tokyo metro (Tozai Line) and 20-minute walk from Tokyo station. The room is quite spacious according to the Japanese standard and price. This hotel is suitable for those who attend a meeting or visit Tokyo for a business trip. It is relatively away from shopping area (Tokyo station area, Ginza,......) despite only one or two stops from those shopping center. Those who like jogging will enjoy jogging around the park on the sidewalk. The dinning room for breakfast is located on the 12th floor with the nice view of the park. It is a compensation for the average breakfast. Staffs are very nice and most are very helpful. However,the hotel management has to improve communication and English skill especially for staff at the concierge.

I love this hotel, subway is right in the front, and the room is lovely. I was going to rate 5 stars but just ran into a problem with the front desk. I'm only here for 3 nights, booked shuttle (Airport Limousine) round trip from/to Narita from Hotel Grand Palace. But shuttle company told me to call to reserves seats, don't know why i have to do that when i already paid for round trip, anyway that's another story. My problem with KKR front desk was, i was having a hard time communicate with the fd staff, had to use my Google translator, asked him to call shuttle company for me to reserves the seats, he said NO. I then asked can I use their phone at the desk to call, he said NO because customer cannot use their phone. Then what am i going to do? Paid 100 yen per minute from the room or go outside and buy a Japanese sim card just to make 1 call? Ridiculous!I'm currently in the room to write this review because i was so mad with the answers. I mean, how much would it cost the hotel to call a local number that he refused for me to borrow it? And what kind of hotel doesn't let guests use the phone to call local number?Was so happy when i arrived and being enjoying my trip, but now it just ruined my day with KKR & AIRPORT LIMOUSINE!

This hotel, which is located in a quiet part of the city centre, was booked for me by a friend. I found it to be very comfortable and clean and the room was good, although a little small by European or N.American standards. The desk staff were conversant in English and the breakfast was both western and Japanese style. The only quibble I would make about the restaurant is that it closed at 09.00, a little early and on one morning I and other residents were informed (politely, of course) at 09.10 that it was closing. Although in a quiet part of the city the Takabashi Metro is just outside and the Otemachi/Tokyo station complex only one stop away. Nearby amenities are available across the road in the Palaceview building, which has two floors of coffee shops and restaurants. This is very much a Japanese hotel as on some mornings I was the only Westerner at breakfast. Not that I found that a problem at all. Would I stay again? Yes.

I have spent 8 nights in this hotel during my trip to Tokyo in April 2016.The most positive aspect is the hotel's location, next to the Emperors Palace and the Takebashi subway station, you can get everywhere within minutes. Additionally, you have a nice view on the Emperors garden during breakfast. Breakfast itself is ok, there's Japanese and Western style buffet. As I have been there as a tourist I normally want to sleep longer, unfortunately breakfast closes at 9 am which is a little early. 10 am would be even better. If you miss breakfast you can have some breakfast in the lobby, but this is extremely expensive (about €6 for a cappuccino). Better get up early.The hotel rooms are what you would expect in Japan, small but with everything you need (TV, water heater, tub). But for two persons it is too small, there's no cupboard anywhere, just a bar when you enter to hang some clothes. For one person this is ok, but for two there wasn't enough space. The service in the hotel is typical Japanese - excellent. Nothing to complain about, they would do anything for you. There's free WiFi as well.As a tip, you should try lunch in the hotel, it is a buffet with everything you need any very affordable. I would visit this hotel again.

Stayed here on a business trip to Tokyo. I have come to appreciate the simpleness of hotels in Japan. Addition by subtraction allows the focus to be on cleanliness and comfort. These are the two components that contribute to a great stay. KKR excels in this area.

I stayed here for 5 nites from 24th to 28th October as one of the recommended hotels for a conference that was being held at the Hitobashi Hall five minutes walk away. It is located opposite the lmperial Palace of Tokyo and the Takebashi Metro station of the is just outside the main entrance. This metro connects me to all the parts of the city through the various connecting metro and Japan Railway (JR) lines. To come here from the Narita lnternational Airport, l took the Airport Limosine Bus that cost ¥3,100 to Palace Hotel, a ten minute walk along the walking path that surrounds the lmperial Palace Garden moat. It is a 15/20 minute walk to the Tokyo Station, the main transportation hub of Tokyo. The reception was excellent and most of them could understand English. They were helpful and gave me a good map and showed me how to negotiate the metro which is quite daunting if you are not familar. The single room that l booked was spacious and clean with a fridge n tv. Some of the rooms overlook the lmperial Palace Gardens. The rooms are from the 13 to 15th floor and all have some view of the Palace. The only setback is that they do not have a safe in the room. Breakfast spread was fairly average; a mixture of japanese and western. Overall l love this hotel although l have to take the metro to the various tourist attractions. A 7-11 is located a mere 2 minutes walk north. If you are looking for a decent hotel with a metro station that connects you to all parts of Tokyo, this is it. The room rate is competitive.

The hotel is located near the northern part of Tokyo Imperial Palace, which can be evaluated as one of the most beautiful city parks in the world. I spent here five wonderful nights in a clean and cosy room in the second half of September during my participation in scientific conference. It was my pleasant time to have a very good Japanese style breakfast near the panoramic window at 12th floor. The staff was polite and very careful like it can be in Japan only. Quite conveniently that KKR is geometric place of points almost equally distant from touristic zones Asakusa, Roppongi, Ueno, Shinjuku and Ginza. Don't worry about an umbrella in a rainy day because they will give it to you...

Roomy Deluxe room with fine view of the Imperial Palace. Quite,clean and convinient location with Toei Subway entrance at the front of the hotel. Also, Tokyo station is 10 minute walk. Gòod breakfast srved with western and Japanese one, though the same classical music was played every morning. Staff is very helpful and warm.

This hotel is in a great location, right next to the imperial palace and its garden. I used this hotel as a base from which I could explore the city of Tokyo. And I found it to be ideally suited for this task. It is right next to an exit to the Takebashi subway station, through which the Tozai-line runs. On rainy days the management of the hotel offered me an umbrella to use, for which I was really grateful, as mine broke a few days earlier. The staff was really helpful with answering any questions I had. One of the biggest pro`s to staying here was that there was a coin washing and drying machine on the 15th floor. It was so ideally suited for my needs, that the next time I am visiting Tokyo, I will try and stay here again.

I stayed at KKR for 3 nights in August, the location of the hotel is excellent (Exit 3B at Takebashi metro station takes you straight to the hotel entrance). The staff seemed very friendly, although I only spoke to them during check in and check out. I stayed in a Deluxe Single Room (double bed) and for Tokyo - it's pretty spacious. Also, the 'Deluxe' option meant that I had a good city view, with Tokyo Skytree in the distance. I had no issues with noise or air con. My only criticism is the condition of the room, there were obvious scratches and marks on the wall and almost every piece of furniture. However, that didn't really affect my stay. There are vending machines on each floor + free wifi in rooms, which I found particularly useful. All in all, it was a nice stay, if what you are looking for is a convenient & comfortable base in the centre of Tokyo, KKR is definitely worth checking out.P.S. There is not a lot to do nearby, but it is right next to the Imperial Palace. Saying that, most attractions and popular districts are just minutes away on the metro.

I stayed here for six days while attending a workshop near Tokyo station. This Japanese run hotel is of good standard. The view over the park from the dining floor is exceptional. The location is great for shopping near the station area but also for running around the park. There is a metro station at the hotel entrance.

Close to my work needs this is a comfortable hotel to stay at. Small rooms but suitable for short visits. Air conditioning does not stay on when you leave he room which makes it uncomfortable on hot and humid days when you return. Views of the Emporer's Palace and gardens are very nice.

Reasonably priced hotel across from Imperial Palace compound/park convenient to many corporations and right in front of major train/subway line. Room was comfortable and views were great. Hotel bar on top (or near top) was very nice. The only issue I had was about getting taxis. It seems not many taxis stop here so I had to wait several minutes on a few occasions. Leave extra time if you need a taxi or just take the train.
user_name:
ericraheemsmith
Croton on Hudson, New York

review_body: Stayed here for the first time. very reasonable price. Rooms a little old fashioned. Staff very helpful. Best part - other than general location, is the view from the breakfast room. Right across the park. Lovely.
user_name:
stumack
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The KKR is a very nice four-star business / banquets hotel in central Tokyo, located right on top of the Takebashi metro station. It is within walking distance of Tokyo Station with hand-luggage (but for wheeled luggage take a taxi). Note that in Japan taxi drivers don't speak English and don't know the names of hotels; make sure you have a print-out of the Japanese website address of the hotel with you to give the driver.Rooms are comfortable and up-to-date. Internet access is free and effective. Our floor had a coin-operated laundry room -- a fantastic convenience. Desk staff speak enough English to check you in and out; the concierge speaks slightly more.The only problem with the hotel is that there are no tourist amenities in the immediate vicinity. Convenience stores are a ten minute walk, supermarkets twenty minutes. There are several coffee shops within 2 or 3 blocks. This is only a minor setback, but the fact is that wherever you want to go in Tokyo OTHER than the Imperial Palace Gardens you will have to take the train. For a hotel more in the middle of things stay in Ginza.Overall: staff were super-courteous, rooms were clean and modern, and the hotel is very nice. It has an in-house wedding chapel and obviously serves mainly as a wedding/banquet venue. Still, that's no reason not to stay there. We were very satisfied.

If you need to be in this area, this is a good choice and price is reasonable for the the financial district. Rooms are small and typical for Japanese business hotels, however there is the option at a higher price, for the larger rooms. If it meets your budget, I suggest you book the larger room. Many rooms have a view of the Imperial Palace and a short walk to it if you have spare time for a relaxing wander through the section of palace grounds. I stayed in the small and larger rooms. Beds are clean and adequately comfortable and the larger room was better equipped. Staff was polite, friendly and helpful though you may encounter problems with English proficiency.Depending on which site you book, breakfast can be included. If you stay several days and not sure if you want breakfast there, skip it and just pay for the days you feel like having breakfast. Didn't have other meals there, though I did look at the dining options and I might just try it the next time I stay. Meal prices are reasonable and would save me time by not scouring the area for a moderately priced meal.Many taxi drivers are not familiar with this hotel as the entrance is somewhat obscure, so it would be prudent to print a map and show them if you don't speak Japanese.

This was a refreshing change from hotels which seek to be a little bit of America. It is a Japanese hotel frequented by their civil service, partly because of its good value for money. It is Japanese not in the sense of kitsch tourist expectations, but offers rooms, facilities, food and drink for the typical Japanese traveler, and does a sideline in weddings with a very nice Christian chapel. (A Chinese and a French restaurant are things the Japanese traveler might appreciate..)It was good to actually feel that I was in a foreign country with an unfamiliar range of food and drink and English rarely heard or seen. Most of the staff are not fluent in English, but reception can always help you.There is a shopping center very close by (but easily overlooked - it is quite discreet on the outside) which has a whole range of international eating places (including some western ones) if you want a change from the hotel food, or if there is too much of a queue at lunchtime. Many people come in from outside for the Chinese lunch at this hotel, so it can get busy.I would say if you are visiting Japan for the first time why not stay where the Japanese do?
user_name:
Martin J P
Sheffield, United Kingdom

review_body: KKR Hotel TokyoStayed here six nights, reservation for two deluxe single rooms through Japanican. This old fashioned but yet clean and well-kept hotel offers a very good location and comfort for a Tokyo experience. Guests are mainly Japanese, business men, families etc. There are also wedding ceremonies, a wedding chappel.I recommend to book this hotel and it's deluxe room as those are more spacious than a standard rooms there. You get all the information of this hotel from their website, just search: access and read PDF of room and bed sizes and hotel services from there.Overall a good hotel to stay in Tokyo and best hotel I´ve stayed in Tokyo so far (ryokan stay earlier).Pros:+ We were checked in at 13:00, which was really nice touch after long haul flight. Official check in time is 15:00.+ Room cleaning.+ All rooms are located on 13F-15F.+ Views from room.+ Single deluxe room is 16.8 - 19.2 sqm. Room size varies (standard single 14 sqm).+ Rooms have views into four directions, mainly they have among two of these: Palace, park, city or surroundings (highway).+ A bit firm but comfortable 140cm wide bed in deluxe single room. Good mattresses.+ LCD TV, BBC, CNN, movie channel, Japanese tv.+ Wifi in room incl. and worked fine. Empty fridge. Pyjama, slippers.+ Shower bath, strong water pressure at 14F, decent amenities.+ Working desk, armchair.+ Curtains blocks light from outside.+ Laundry service or self service laundry room at 15F, 300yen per machine plus dryer machine.+ Attentive staff, language skills varies, but they'll make every effort to assist you with a few english words too.+ Quiet room and hallway at night.+ Location: Otemachi station connects most of the subway lines. Exploring Tokyo from this hotel saves travel time as you either get direct subway access e.g. to Shibuya, Shinjuku and Ginza, and travel time is around 10-15min.+ One good modern breakfast place 500m north from hotel, same side of street. Name was "...Tree". Did not use hotel breakfast as it ended at 09:00.Prices 1000-2000yen. More breakfast at Otemachi/ Tokyo station under Marunouchi building B-1.Cons:- Don´t take metro to hotel when coming from airport. Lot´s of walk and stairs in tunnels with luggage. You actually walk to Otemachi station, then you walk more at Takebashi station. There is a sign to KKR Hotel. Take a taxi from Tokyo station with luggage.- Bathroom´s room height lower than in room. - Loud TV voice from next room came strangely through window in two evenings, but ended soon.- If hotel´d filled with Americans having jet lag and loud conversations in a hallway, that will be heard into room. However there were no disturbances at night at all. There is a small opening under room door into hallway.- There were grapejuice or something spilled on fresh pyjama, no idea where that came from. - A bit old style hotel, however facilities are clean and well well-kept.

We had a room with a decent view. However, our air condition was a little noisy. But we were happy with the location which was most important. Staff couldnt understand English very well but we got by.

I stayed at the KKR for 8 nights out of 10 during a recent trip to Japan on a fellowship, so I got to know the hotel quite well. The place was certainly serviceable, and probably 3.5 stars would be more accurate, but a few minor problems keep me from bumping it up to the elusive four star "very good" category.The location of the hotel is definitely a plus. It is located right near the Imperial Palace, and indeed from the restaurant on the 12th floor you can look right into the gardens. Definitely a nice view, and a great place to go walking/jogging in the morning. Located right beneath the hotel is the Tokyo Subway (Tozai line) so that you can easily hop on the metro and ride around town. There is a food court type area located around the hotel, and it's walking distance from nice restaurants (and karaoke, if that's your thing).The staff was friendly and helpful. In another review someone complained about the English, but I (as someone who speaks no Japanese) was always able to find an employee to help me. The concierge staff was particularly pleasant, helping with everything from locating an ATM to finding out information on a baseball game to changing money.Breakfast at the Fuyo restaurant was nice, although very repetitive. I think a little variety in the selection would have been nice, although I suppose they don't generally anticipate guests staying there for eight days at a time. Nonetheless, if you have extended business to do at the hotel, keep that in mind.I found rooms to be somewhat small, although certainly workable. I would not, however, want to spend a lot of time inside. The beds were pretty hard; I normally like a more rigid mattress, but this was too much even for me.One major problem was the lack of good Wifi, particularly on the 15th floor. For the first part of my trip (I checked out for two nights then checked back in) I was on the top floor and shut out of Wifi. I had to go all the way down to the lobby in order to get a signal, and that one was unsecured. My colleagues below me on the 14th floor had a signal. When I checked back in and was given a room on the 13th, I had a signal. It appears, therefore, that the 15th floor is a dead zone. This hotel seems to cater more as a business hotel (given room size and what-not, I'd struggle to use this as a tourist point) and therefore reliable Wifi seems extremely important. I think the hotel really needs to address this issue.Overall, I did enjoy my stay here. Staff was nice, location pretty good, and food okay (while repetitive). However, after a few nights, you begin to pick up on a bunch of things that could be better.

Good scenery , double bed with large width, clean room, adequate amenity goods, comfortable pajama, wired internet connection, blackout curtain. They scored high point.Noise by air conditioner, close of almost restaurants & bar on Sat,Sun and national holiday.They scored low points.

Stayed at the hotel booked through Agoda based on its description and the location - it is indeed handy for the Imperial Palace an dthe rooms are small but ok...and there it ends. Only the Japanese restaurant was open at the weekend (but it was ok!). Asked the staff to book a taxi to the airport for an early flight in the morning - concierge called at 2000 to say he had not managed to book one yet...what he did nto say was that he was giving up! luckily managed to get one in the morning but could have been different! Give this one a miss and stay at the Prince just arounf the corner! and no gym!
user_name:
Robert T
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: I've used this hotel a number of times. The rooms aren't huge, but I love the views, on a clear day you can see Mount Fuji. The internet is free and reliable. I'm sure it's not the cheapest place in the city, but it's a good hotel for a business trip.

PLUSES1. Very quiet room. Also very nice and clean.2. Shower was wonderful. Water was strong and hot enough 3. So many choices of snacks, drinks and food available on the vending machines4. It was located just next to Metro so it was sort of convenient5. Free internet accessMINUSES1. Don't take metro to this hotel though if you will carry heavy luggage as there is no elavator at the exit of metro to this hotel2. Communicating with staff was the most frustrating part throughout my stay. They didn't understand what I wanted. They could speak very little English. 3. Toilet paper was of poor quality.4. The mattress was hard. My body, particularly the upper back, felt painful every morning when I woke up.

The hotel is OK. Rooms are clean, not so spacious but good enough, and the comfort room is great and outfitted with bidets. This is good for business travelers as it is very near the central business district/area. The breakfast buffet can be improved though. There are only a few choice of food but the view outside from the dining area is great. The only drawback is that not all the hotel personnel, specifically the front desk, can speak and understand English so you have to budget more time when checking out as sometimes, they need to ask somebody who speaks/understands English to deal with you. The hotel personnel though are very polite and helpful.It's good if your room is facing the Imperial Palace grounds as it gives you a nice early morning and early evening view of the palace grounds and the moat surrounding the palace. On your free time, you can walk to the Imperial palace grounds as it is very near the hotel. Enjoy a leisurely walk along the vast grounds, get some sun, or just idle away. It's a good place to relax, meet other people/tourists, and learn more on Japan's royal family. Another good thing with Japan is that they have a very organized public transportation system, e.g train, from my limited experience that is. Also, I must say the discipline of the people/citizen is something to look up to, eg. traffic rules, simple road courtesies, crossing the road, riding an escalator, etc.

This is a great central location for Tokyo, with a subway (Takabashi) for the Tozai line at the door (get a Suica Card- it saved alot of time and made things very simple). Inexpensive eating 10 min walk away toward Kanda Station, and a 7-11, McDonalds, and approx 15 good restaurants one block away toward the Imperial Palace Gate (Tababashi Bridge Exit). Clean, and good value at Y18,000 something per night. Central to get to many locations and walkable fromTokyo Station.Some rooms over look the Imperial Palace Gardens. Highly recommend. Internet connection in room, adapter plugs etc available at reception.It is a business Hotel but I think it offers great value (very tidy/high standard) compared to tourist-specific hotels.

The lobby of the hotel is very nice, but the rooms do not live up to the same standard. Although clean and tidy the decor is outdated and the combi air con / radio unit looked very old! Free internet access was a plus though.The location is not great as it's slightly out of the way for sightseeing although it is right next to the imperial palace. We arrived using the subway as it's directly connected to Takebashi station, but the walk with heavy cases and few escalators made us wish we'd either walked from Tokyo station (only 15 minutes) or got a taxi. There is also not many restaurants nearby.The staff were very friendly and happy to help although their English wasn't great, but it was better than my Japanese!

This is the third time I have been at the KKR, and each has been a mixed experience. On the plus side, the staff are excellent, always willing to help and unfailingly polite. My rooms have been clean, and everything has worked. The bathrooms are fine, with sufficient water pressure and equipped with one of the wonderful Japanese toilets. The views of the Imperial Palace from the room are good, but you must be on the correct side of the hotel to have one. Internet access is very good.One the minus side: the hotel is showing its age, one finds peeling wallpaper in places. The breakfasts are overpriced. Tall people must duck to avoid hitting heads on fire door frames. The heating / A/C in the rooms is difficult to control. The area around the hotel is dead -- it is hard to find a place to eat after 9:00. I frequently heard noise from the adjoining rooms.I stay here because it is convenient for where I need to be during the day, and have no problem recommending the hotel on that basis. I would not stay in this hotel as a tourist, but would strongly prefer a more alive area like Shijuku.

While the KKR wasn't horrible, it wasn't a pleasant experience, either. The rooms (we stayed in two different rooms) smelled of stale cigarette smoke. The signs posted asking guests not to smoke in bed were telling, as well as ominous. The air conditioning was the kind that only blows hot air, and the combination alarm clock/nightstand seemed to have come out of a '50s B sci-fi film. Kitschy yes, but ultimately about as useful as a chunk of wood. The saving grace of the hotel had to be the staff. Very professional, very polite, and seemingly willing to go out of their way to offer help, tips, and suggestions for the jet-lagged Westerner.
